headline: First euthanasia case
text: In this timeline, we’ll show the cases of euthanasia along the years.

headline: Samual Williams
text:
"An important milestone in the euthanasia debate was the isolation of morphine in the nineteenth century and its widespread use as an analgesic [a pain-relieving agent]... When the practice of analgesia had become reasonably well established, Samuel Williams, a nonphysician, began to advocate the use of these drugs not only to alleviate terminal pain but to intentionally end a patient's life..."

Williams' euthanasia proposal received serious attention in the medical journals and at scientific meetings Michael Manning
mediaCaption: James Gillray, Bleeding a Vein, circa 1804.

headline: ...100 years of developement later
text: Associations and discussions around the topic continue to be created. Support groups are founded but also groups fighting against the idea and its implementation.

headline: World Federation of Right to Die Societies
text:
The World Federation of Right to Die Societies was founded. Its membership included dozens of organizations from countries around the world that were concerned with euthanasia and the right to die.

Check out their website
mediaCaption: World Federation of Right to Die Societies Logo

headline: US Supreme Court Rules There is No Right To Die
text: The Supreme Court rules in Washington v. Glucksberg and Vacco v. Quill that there is not a constitutional right to die.

headline: Netherlands legalizes Euthanasia
text:
The Netherlands becomes the first European country, and the first country worldwide to officially legalize Euthanasia.

There are various ways to intentionally expedite the end of life. Euthanasia is the most explicit and is performed only when the patient has clearly expressed the wish to die. The Netherlands has statutory rules and procedures for the termination of life on request.

headline: Luxembourg Legalizes Euthanasia
text:
The most important part of the law is the guarantee that doctors performing active euthanasia or assisting to commit suicide will not be liable to prosecution. The condition for this is that the patient should be terminally ill and in insufferable pain, and should voluntarily, deliberately and repeatedly confirm in writing their desire to end their own life.

Luxembourg was the third European Union member state and the third state worldwide to legalize euthanasia.

headline: Belgium's Removal of Age Restriction for Euthanasia
text:
On March 2, 2014, Belgium’s King Philippe signed into law an amendment to that country’s euthanasia law. Under this new law, a child who is terminally ill, who suffers from intolerable and inescapable physical pain, whose capacity for understanding and judgment (“capacité de discernement”) has been verified by a psychologist, and whose parents consent may request medically assisted suicide.

Belgium became the world’s first country to lift all age restrictions on euthanasia.
mediaCaption: going behind the most liberal euthanasia laws in the world

headline: Physician-Assisted Suicide Becomes Legal in Canada
text: On 17 June 2016, Bill C-14 to legalized and regulated assisted dying, which passed in Canada's Parliament. Strict rules govern access to assisted suicide. If they are not met, anyone who aids another person in killing themselves is guilty of a crime. Canada's law on assisted dying does not allow advance directives, nor does it allow it for minors or people who are suffering from a mental illness.

headline: Aurelia Brouwers dies by euthanasia
text:
In January a young Dutch woman drank poison supplied by a doctor and lay down to die. Euthanasia and doctor-assisted suicide are legal in the Netherlands, so hers was a death sanctioned by the state. But Aurelia Brouwers was not terminally ill - she was allowed to end her life on account of her psychiatric illness.

check out her Instagram

headline: Germany overturns ban on organized assisted suicide
text: On 26 February 2020, Germany’s Federal Constitutional Court overturned the ban on organized medical assisted suicide. This allows the terminally and gravely ill to request help to die with dignity, without having to leave the country which was what was quite often practiced previously. With this ruling, Germany will help those suffering and extremely ill, to end their lives in an organized manner with the help of medical practitioners. Germany’s hightest court concluded the right to die includes the freedom to “rely on the voluntary help of another person.”

headline: New Zealand votes to legalize physician-assisted suiced for the terminally ill
text: On 17 October 2020, more than 65% of New Zealanders voted in favour of legalizing physician-assisted suicide for terminally ill adults. The official results were announced on 6 November 2020, and the law came into effect a year later, in November 2021. This law only applies to citizens and permanent residents of New Zealand who are over the age of 18. They must be terminally ill with 6 months or less to live. The patient has to be in an "advanced state of irreversible decline in physical capability" with "unbearable suffering that cannot be relieved in a manner that the person considers tolerable." Lastly, it is essential that the patient is able to make an informed decision regarding the assisted death.
mediaCaption: Prime Minister of New Zealand Jacinda Ardern supports the euthanasia reform

headline: Spain legalizes euthanasia
text: On 25 June 2021, Spain became the fifth country in the world and the fourth in Europe to legalise euthanasia. Spain joined the likes of the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and Canada, in passing the law. The requirements for patients to request their life be ended, are that the affected person must “suffer a serious or incurable disease or a serious, chronic and incapacitating condition,” which causes them “intolerable suffering.” However, unlike the laws in force in other countries, the Spanish legislation sets out a thorough series of steps that could result in the process taking a month from the patients date of request. The process starts with a written request by the patient and it must be submitted twice over the space of two weeks to ensure the decision has been thought about extensively. The patient is allowed to change their mind at any time and once the second request has be made, the patient’s doctor must allow for and pass the request onto the regional commission. They will then approve or reject the decision based on the circumstances. Before the passing of this law, helping somebody to die in Spain was potentially punishable by a jail term of up to 10 years. Now suffering patients are legally given the option.
mediaCaption: Spanish supporters of the law to legalise euthanasia holding placards protesting for the "right to die in peace" before the law was passed.

headline: First person in Colombia with non-terminal illness dies by legal euthanasia
text: Víctor Escobar, a 60-year-old Colombian carrier, became the first person in the South American country to receive euthanasia who was not suffering from a terminal illness. However, Escobar had several incurable degenerative conditions. He suffered from obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension, as well as having suffered two strokes in 2008. He had mobility problems and needed oxygen on a daily basis. He also had three spinal surgeries after surviving a car crash in his youth. "Victor Escobar requested to donate his functional organs. He died at 9:20 pm on Friday, January 7, 2022 as he wished ," his lawyer, Luis Giraldo, reported on Twitter.
mediaCaption: Víctor Escobar said his final goodbyes in a video published by the newspaper El Tiempo
